div.head: Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth
div.p: The aim of this note is not to attempt an exhaustive listing of books that Ruskin read or consulted in his youth. Throughout ERM, information about the influences of Ruskin's reading is available in the apparatuses and glosses of works that contain specific allusions to and borrowings from publications to which he was exposed. Moreover, especially influential authors and published sources are additionally discussed in notes of their own. This information may be searched by keyword, and relevant biographical and contextual notes are also linked below. The purpose of the present note, rather, is to centralize various information nowhere else referenced in the archive, particularly information about material features and marginalia of books that survive allegedly from the Ruskin family library (provenance is not clear in all cases). Such features are too detailed to have been included in the preeminent enumerative bibliographies, Van Akin Burd's transcriptions of book purchases noted in John James Ruskin's Account Book (RF MS 28, 1827–45), collected by year in notes to Ruskin Family Letters; and James S. Dearden's The Library of John Ruskin. Those sources remain a starting point for investigation of Ruskin's reading.

div.head: Researching Ruskin's Reading
div.p: The simple documented presence of a given title--or for that matter, its absence--can of course tell us only so much about a book's use by members of the family. For example, some of John James's purchases of books designed for youths may have been meant less for Ruskin than for his cousin, Mary Richardson (1815–49), who lived with the Ruskin family from 1828 to her marriage in 1848. About the family library, Dearden comments: "the books owned by all three Ruskins must be considered to be part of 'Ruskin's Library' because he ultimately inherited his parents' possessions, as well as having the use of them during their lifetimes". That availability for use, if not inheritance, may or may not have included Mary Richardson's books. About the known scope of Ruskin's books, Dearden cautiously concludes: "although Ruskin's lifetime's library was much greater than it was at any one time, we do not know its total extent" (Library of John Ruskin, xv, xxiv). In ERM, that scope is extended in apparatuses and glosses, which occasionally are able to point to definite influence of publications that otherwise left no material trace in the records of the family library.

Dearden's view is well taken, too, that in adulthood Ruskin "was essentially . . . a book-buyer rather than a book borrower or library user" (Library of John Ruskin, xix). Ruskin seems to have inherited this habit from his father, who was generous with books for his son's education and entertainment. Borrowing cannot be dismissed, however, as a source for family reading. On travels, the Ruskins supplemented books they brought with them by tapping resources for English readers along the way, such as when Mary Richardson cheered up John, who had taken ill while touring Switzerland in 1833, by finding him "some English books from a library" along with "2 or 3 volumes of Gagliani's Magazine" (i.e., probably one of the periodicals issued by Librairie Galignani, the Paris-based English-language publisher, bookseller, and circulating library, which published a monthly, the Repertory of English Literature [begun 1808], and a daily, Gaglinani's Messenger [begun 1814]) (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 106). At home, Margaret Ruskin appears to refer to borrowing when, for example, she writes to Jahn James about the novel, The Fool of Quality (1766-72) by Henry Brooke (1703-83), of which she "got the first volume merely to read the History of the three little fishes to John", since she otherwise "did not like" the book (Margaret to John James Ruskin, 15 May 1826, RFL 145). The episode may illustrate Margaret's caution about allowing books in the house that she considered harmful. (In this case, "the Almighty open[ed] the understanding" in her renewed encounter with the novel, committing her to "read it together" with John James. Perhaps she obtained a copy in John Wesley's abridgement.)

A caveat should also be applied to Ruskin's own account of his boyhood reading in Praeterita. The authors and titles he names are not untrue to his early reading, but the account has charmed readers into fixating on a short list of titles that is potentially misleading. The selectiveness of the list--for example, contrasting the enforced Sunday reading of John Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress and Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe with "reading of my own election" on weekdays of Walter Scott's novels and Homer (Alexander Pope's translation of the Iliad)--is calculated to establish the autobiography's gently comic, ironic tone, but also instills the impression that Ruskin's study of these books was both simultaneous and compartmentalized. The impression obscures the graduated program of reading that Ruskin's parents set for his education as well as the sometimes eccentric and resistant approach that Ruskin took to that program. While there must always have been compartmentalization yet overlap of kinds of study--routine times of day devoted respectively to Bible reading, lessons, and leisure reading--the early manuscripts reflect the tiered plan for instruction that educationists had popularized since the late eighteenth century. Ruskin's schooling in the secular ethical and scientific dialogues of Letitia Barbauld, the Edgeworths, Thomas Day, and Jeremiah Joyce was largely confined to early years, ca. 1826-29, while serious religious study succeeded that stage, starting in 1829. At the same time, the boy tended to defy the program, skipping ahead to dialogues meant for older children. Some of his imaginative reading, meanwhile, such as Walter Scott's The Monastery, wrought an effect on his religious life as profound as the sermons he started to study at the same time.

Dearden helpfully annotates his entries with provenance and other information, and Burd connects John James's brief notations of authors/titles and amounts spent on book purchases with editions available at the time from publishers at those prices. Burd's transcriptions should nonetheless be compared against the manuscript of the Account Book, since John James's entries are sometimes ambiguous, warranting closer scrutiny. For convenience of reference, there follow the locations of Burd's transcriptions of book lists in Ruskin Family Letters, along with the corresponding pages of John James's accounting of "Sundries", which is how he caregorized books along with other non-perishable household items, subdivided by month of purchase.

One year of sundry book purchases, those for 1830, was omitted by Burd in Ruskin Family Letters, presumably because no letters from that year are extant, thus giving no occasion for annotation. Dearden has incorporated some of this information into the alphabetized entries in The Library of John Ruskin. Because chronological lists are particularly salient to ERM, however, John James's 1830 book list is supplied in its integrity, cross-referenced with entries in Dearden. Names are transcribed that may or may not refer to authors (John James often listed vendors by name, in place of the wares they supplied, as well as recipients of gifts or purchases). These identifications remain in process.

John Aiken and Anna Laetitia Barbauld, Evenings at Home

A copy with a Brantwood bookplate now at the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., may survive from Ruskin boyhood: Evenings at Home; / or the / Juvenile Budget Opened. / consisting of / a Variety of Miscellaneous Pieces / for the / Instruction and Amusement / of / Young Persons / by Dr. Aiken and Mrs. Barbauld / London / Printed and Published by J. F. Dove, / St. John Square.

The copy contains marginalia in Ruskinʼs mature hand, especially the pages containing the twenty‐first evening, which is connected with mineralogy (Viljoen, Ruskinʼs Backgrounds 8). Scrawls on the front endpaper may be Ruskinʼs from childhood: one of these scrawls Helen Gill Viljoen read as a “J”, and she declared this to be Ruskinʼs earliest extant signature (where does she say so? not in Backgrounds where she assigns earliest signature to Frank—maybe she thought better of it ).
See Anna Laetitia Barbauld, and, in connection with her influence, “The Needless Alarm”: Discusssion.
Maria Edgeworth, “Harry and Lucy Concluded”; although owned by Ruskin, may or may not have been his boyhood copy.
Maria Edgeworth, “Harry and Lucy Concluded” (Ruskinʼs copy)

A copy owned by Ruskin with a Brantwood bookplate was acquired by Sharp (Viljoen, Ruskinʼ Backgrounds, 7). Sharp gave his collection to Helen Gill Viljoen, who in turn, in dividing her collection between libraries, gave the Ruskin books in her possession to the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., where this copy of “Harry and Lucy Concluded” remains.
The copy is a first (1825) edition .

It is unclear whether this copy is the one that Ruskin used in childhood. The binding is tight and the pages clean, as compared with Ruskinʼs boyhood copy of Edgeworth, Frank, which and which contains marginalia in Ruskinʼs boyhood as well as mature hands. All the marginalia in Ruskinʼs “Harry and Lucy Concluded” is in Ruskinʼs mature hand; however, a crude geometrical drawing on the back endpaper of volume 4 may date from boyhood .
Maria Edgeworth, Frank (Ruskinʼs copy)

A copy owned by Ruskin with a Brantwood bookplate was acquired by Sharp (Viljoen, Ruskinʼs Backgrounds, 6). Sharp gave his collection to Helen Gill Viljoen, who in turn, in dividing her collection between libraries, gave the Ruskin books in her possession to the Beinecke Library, Yale University, New Haven, Conn., where this copy of Frank remains.
The copy is a first (1822) edition in three volumes .

The volumes, which have had heavy use , contain marginalia in the hand of one of his parents and in Ruskinʼs—both his boyhood and mature hands. The first volume has an inscription, “John Ruskin,” on the first flyleaf (recto), which Viljoen identifies as the hand of John James Ruskin; then, on a blank page which follows [i.e., the second flyleaf, recto], [is] Ruskinʼs earliest known signature , a pencilled one Ruskin apparently copied, in a most childish scrawl, from the name as written in ink by his Father (ibid.). Whether this is indeed Ruskin earliest extant signature cannot be determined, but the cursive script, which Ruskin did not generally adopt before , is indeed very labored.
The endpapers () of volume 1 also contain Frank drawing, untitled no. 1, and Frank drawing, untitled no. 2.
Daniel Defoe, Robinson Crusoe, allegedly a two–volume 1812 edition of The Life and Surprising Adventures of Robinson Crusoe (Ruskin Family Letters 150 n. 4).

list.item: Children in the Wood; Sinbad the Sailor: In 1823, to mollify John during an illness, Margaret Ruskin was "obliged to buy I don't know how many books". Worried that John James might duplicate a purchase, she recommended he bring home these traditional tales (Margaret to John James Ruskin, 11 March 1823, RFL 126-27 and see 127l no. 1).
